title: Internal security
text:
Internal security is the act of keeping peace within the <a href="border">border</a>s of a <a href="sovereign%20state">sovereign state</a> or other <a href="Self-governance">self-governing territories</a>, generally by upholding the national <a href="law">law</a> and defending against internal security threats. Responsibility for internal security may range from <a href="police">police</a> to <a href="paramilitary">paramilitary</a> forces, and in exceptional circumstances, the <a href="military">military</a> itself.
Threats to internal security.
Threats to the general peace may range from low-level <a href="civil%20order">civil order</a>, large scale <a href="violence">violence</a>, or even an armed <a href="insurgency">insurgency</a>. Threats to internal security may be directed at either the state's <a href="citizen">citizen</a>s, or the organs and infrastructure of <a href="State%20%28polity%29">the state</a> itself, and may range from petty <a href="crime">crime</a>, serious <a href="organised%20crime">organized crime</a>, political or industrial unrest, or even domestic <a href="terrorism">terrorism</a>. Foreign powers may also act as a threat to internal security, by either committing or sponsoring terrorism or <a href="rebellion">rebellion</a>, without actually <a href="Declaration%20of%20war">declaring war</a>.
Governmental responsibility for internal security will generally rest with an <a href="interior%20ministry">interior ministry</a>, as opposed to a <a href="Defence%20minister">defence ministry</a>. Depending on the state, a state's internal security will be maintained by either the ordinary <a href="police">police</a> or more militarised security forces (known as <a href="Gendarmerie">Gendarmerie</a> or, literally, the <a href="Internal%20Troops">Internal Troops</a>.). Other specialized internal security agencies may exist to augment these main forces, such as <a href="border%20guard">border guard</a>s, <a href="List%20of%20special%20law%20enforcement%20units">special police unit</a>s, or aspects of the state's <a href="Intelligence%20agency">intelligence agencies</a>. In some states, internal security may be the primary responsibility of a <a href="secret%20police">secret police</a> force.
The level of authorized force used by agencies and forces responsible for maintaining internal security might range from unarmed <a href="police">police</a> to fully armed <a href="paramilitary">paramilitary</a> organizations, or employ some level of <a href="less-lethal%20weapon">less-lethal weapon</a>ry in between. For violent situations, internal security forces may contain some element of military type equipment such as <a href="non-military%20armored%20vehicles">non-military armored vehicles</a>.
Justice aspects.
Depending on the organization of the state, internal security forces may have <a href="jurisdiction">jurisdiction</a> on national or <a href="Federation">federal</a> levels. As the concept of internal security refers to the entity of the state and its citizens, persons who are threats to internal security may be designated as an <a href="enemy%20of%20the%20state">enemy of the state</a> or <a href="enemy%20of%20the%20people">enemy of the people</a>.
Persons detained by internal security forces may either be dealt with by the normal <a href="criminal%20justice">criminal justice</a> system, or for more serious crimes against internal security such as <a href="treason">treason</a>, they may face special measures such as <a href="secret%20trial">secret trial</a>s. In times of extreme unrest, internal security actions may include measures such as <a href="internment">internment</a> (detention without trial).
Relationship with the military.
Depending on the nature of the specific state's <a href="form%20of%20government">form of government</a>, enforcing internal security will generally not be carried out by a country's <a href="military">military</a> forces, whose primary role is external defense, except in times of extreme unrest or other <a href="state%20of%20emergency">state of emergency</a>, short of <a href="civil%20war">civil war</a>. Often, military involvement in internal security is explicitly prohibited, or is restricted to authorized <a href="military%20aid%20to%20the%20civil%20power">military aid to the civil power</a> as part of the principle of <a href="civilian%20control%20of%20the%20military">civilian control of the military</a>. Military <a href="List%20of%20special%20forces%20units">special forces units</a> may in some cases be put under the temporary command of civilian powers, for special internal security situations such as <a href="counter%20terrorism">counter terrorism</a> operations.
